resources.string: A Native Android Application that demonstrates Secure Mobile Development Practises.
Welcome. Clicking this button on each view inside the App will give you more information about the different security measures implemented.

The Authentication and Access Control is provided by the OpenID Connect standard. The Open Source Identity and Access Management Server, Keycloak, is being used as the Identity Provider. 

This App uses the Authorization Code flow and saves the tokens to Shared Preferences in WORLD_PRIVATE mode. 

Certificate pinning is being used for the Authentication Server. A Base64 encoded Subject Public Key Information (SPKI) fingerprint is being pinned in the mobile app which is verified against the presented certificate.

The notes are encrypted automatically when saved locally. It supports 2 storage options, using file system or sqlite. 

When saved in the file system, each note is saved in its own file, and encrypted with its own secret key. The secret keys are persisted in the Android Keystore. 
To encrypt the files, AES is used. The key size is 128 bit, with GCM mode to ensure the integrity of the data. 

When saved in sqlite database, SqlCipher library is used to encrypt the whole database. 

For Android versions below 23, the secret keys can not be generated using the keystore. Instead, a KeyPair is generated in the keystore, and the secret key is generated separately. Then the public key is used to encrypt the secret key and the encrypted secret key is persisted using the private SharedPrefereneces of the app. To load the encrypted files, the encrypted secret key will be decrypted first using the private key.
The Users Identity and Access Data is being retrieved from the OpenID Connect Access Token. \n\nThe remote endpoint terminates the existing session when the user logs out.

There are a number of role checks performed here to indicate if the users Access Token grants them access to a number of predefined roles in the mobile app. \n\nTo enter this view, the user must at least possess the mobile-user role.

The Application assesses the environment around it to learn how the Application is being run. 

The application can detect if it is being run in an emulator by looking for evidence in the system properties. 

The application also detects if an Android debugger is attached to the application. 

Root Access is detected using a number of techniques including checking for root management apps, root cloaking apps, busybox binaries etc. 

The app will also detect if a user has setup a device lock screen using a pin, password, pattern etc. 

Hooking framework binaries like Cydia Substrate and the Xposed Framework will also be scanned for. 

A number of other checks are performed to see if it is possible to recover application data using the android backup function, check if device encryption is being used, check that the device is using the latest Android version and detecting if the developer mode is enabled.

Before being allowed to upload notes to the API server, the user\'s permission is checked on the client. The API server endpoints are also protected by the same role check. \n\nTo ensure the security of the data during transmission, certificate pinning is used to check the identity of the server.
